article_text:
On Tuesday, Russian invaders launched a missile attack on Pavlohrad (Dnipropetrovsk region), killing one person, and the local railway station Pavlohrad-2 was destroyed, according to Head of Dnipropetrovsk Regional Military Administration Valentyn Reznichenko.

"Rocket strikes in Pavlohrad. The Pavlohrad-2 railway station was destroyed. The railway track and rails were destroyed. 15 freight cars derailed. One person has been killed. Traffic through the station was stopped for an indefinite time," Reznichenko said on the Telegram channel.

article_author: ['Travis Caldwell', "Se√°n Federico O'Murch√∫", 'Sana Noor Haq', 'Lauren Said-Moorhouse', 'Kathryn Snowdon', 'Adrienne Vogt']
article_text:
It's nighttime in Ukraine. These are the key takeaways from Tuesday so far:

Belarus could join war: The US and NATO believe that Belarus could ‚Äúsoon‚Äù join Russia in its war against Ukraine, US and NATO officials tell CNN, and that the country is already taking steps to do so. It is increasingly ‚Äúlikely‚Äù that Belarus will enter the conflict, a NATO military official said on Monday.

Ukrainians fighting to reclaim territory: Ukrainians forces have now been trying to take back territory in the last few days that the Russians had gained, according to a senior US defense official, calling them ‚Äúable and willing‚Äù to do so.

Ukrainian forces have regained control of Makariv, a town 30 miles west of Kyiv, the Armed Forces of Ukraine said in a post on Facebook on Tuesday. Meanwhile, the mayor of Boryspil, a city to the east of the capital, is calling on residents to leave, saying "fighting is already raging around the region" in a video statement posted to Facebook.

Dwindling supplies: Some towns in Ukraine don‚Äôt have more than three or four days‚Äô worth of food, the aid agency Mercy Corps said Tuesday, warning that the humanitarian system in the country ‚Äúis entirely broken down.‚Äù

Food and medical supplies have almost run out in the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson, according to spokesperson for Ukraine‚Äôs Ministry of Foreign Affairs Oleg Nikolenko.

Refugees: More than 3.5 million refugees have now fled Ukraine, according to the latest update from the UN Refugee Agency.

About half a million refugees who have fled the war in Ukraine to Poland require support for mental health disorders, and 30,000 are estimated to have severe mental health problems, the World Health Organization‚Äôs representative in Poland said Tuesday.

Kateryna Tyshchenko ‚Äì Tuesday, 22 March 2022, 18:52

Russian troops destroyed a railway station with a missile strike in Pavlohrad (Dnipropetrovsk region). One person was killed.



Source: Valentyn Reznichenko, Head of Dnipropetrovsk Regional Military Administration, on Telegram.



Quote: "Missile strikes in Pavlohrad. A railway station Pavlohrad-2 has been destroyed. Railway tracks have been destroyed. 15 freight cars derailed. One person was killed."



Details: Reznichenko informed that the movement of trains through Pavlohrad-2 station was suspended for an indefinite period.

On Tuesday, March 22, a rocket attack was launched on Pavlograd. As a result, one person died.

The blow hit the Pavlograd-2 train station. This was reported by Informant, referring to the post of head of the Dnepropetrovsk OVA Valentin Reznichenko.

‚ÄúRailroads and rails were destroyed. 15 freight vehicles were derailed. One person was killed. Traffic at the station stopped for an indefinite period,‚Äù Valentin Reznichenko wrote.

Earlier, we reported that units of the Dnepropetrovsk region shot down a drone and two aggressor planes. They also wrote that an enemy drone was shot down over the Dnepropetrovsk region.

Plato Berezhnoy

Russian troops launched missile strikes on Pavlograd, Dnipropetrovsk region.

The head of the Dnipropetrovsk Valent–Ωn Reznichenko reported about it in the telegram channel, informs Censor.NET.

"Missile strikes in Pavlograd. Pavlograd-2 railway station destroyed. The railway line and tracks were destroyed. 15 freight cars derailed. One person died. Traffic through the station was suspended indefinitely," he wrote.
